name: Amobarbital (Amytal)
summary: A short- to intermediate-acting barbiturate formerly used for insomnia, anxiety, and as a pre-anesthetic agent.
description: Amobarbital is a barbiturate that depresses the central nervous system by enhancing GABAergic inhibition at the GABA-A receptor. Historically marketed as Amytal, it was used for insomnia, acute anxiety, sedation, and as part of 'narcoanalysis' in psychiatry. Due to risks of dependence, overdose, and the availability of safer alternatives, it is now rarely used in most countries.

sections.text: Enhances the effect of GABA at the GABA-A receptor by increasing the duration of chloride channel opening, leading to CNS depression.

adult.start: 65–200 mg orally at bedtime for insomnia (historical dosing)
adult.titrate: Not typically titrated; use minimal effective dose
adult.max: No longer recommended for routine use

sections.geriatric: Avoid due to high fall and cognitive impairment risk

sections.text: Onset within 15–30 minutes orally; duration of sedation 6–8 hours.

other: High risk of dependence and withdrawal
Avoid combining with alcohol or other CNS depressants

sections.pregnancy: Avoid unless absolutely necessary; potential teratogenicity and neonatal withdrawal.
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; may cause sedation and respiratory depression in infant.
sections.pediatrics: Not recommended except in rare controlled circumstances.
sections.geriatrics: Avoid due to high risk of adverse CNS effects and falls.

sections.text: If used for more than 1–2 weeks, taper slowly to avoid withdrawal seizures.

items: Largely obsolete for insomnia due to benzodiazepines and Z-drugs.
Still of historical interest in psychiatry for 'truth serum' applications.
Highly lethal in overdose—restrict use to highly controlled settings if at all.
